data.title: Define dependencies for repository linux distro
data.body:
Found in the wild:

```
[12436:0327/065126:INFO:CONSOLE(38)] "Error: libxkbfile.so.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory", source: /usr/share/code/resources/app/node_modules/native-keymap/index.js (38)
```

This does not cause a crash, but makes our support of different keyboard layouts fall back to using `e.keyCode` based event dispatching. It would be nice if the `apt-get install vscode` would install this dependency. I am not an expert in this field, but perhaps it is possible to list dependencies?

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22641#issuecomment-289368994

data.title: [json] formatter should keep empty lines

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.0-insider

Steps to Reproduce:

1. `"json.format.enable": true`
2. Place some new lines inside a JSON and press save. New lines are removed.

Use case:

In bigger JSON files - especially ones that allow commenting (e.g. JSON5 or `.vscode/settings.json`) - it is useful, if we could use new lines, but still benefit from formatting.

data.title: Can't --inspect into a remote node container
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: latest-insiders
- OS Version Windows 10 latest:



Debugging a remote node container with legacy debug works just fine with me:
`node --debug=0.0.0.0:5858 --debug-brk index.js`

However doing the same with the newer --inspect, debugging never works
`node --inspect=0.0.0.0:9229 --debug-brk index.js`

NOTES: 
- Ports (5858, 9229) have been exposeds and mapped.
- Docker IP 172.17.0.1
- Node container IP 172.17.0.2 (This is the translated IP by docker)
- Nodejs v7.7.4

configs of --debug: 


      "type": "node",
      "request": "attach",
      "protocol": "legacy",
      "name": "Remote Debug",
      "address": "172.17.0.1",
      "port": 5858,
      "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
      "remoteRoot": "/home/app"


 and --inspect:


      "type": "node",
      "request": "attach",
      "protocol": "inspector",
      "name": "Remote Inspect",
      "address": "172.17.0.1",
      "port": 9229,
      "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
      "remoteRoot": "/home/app",
      "trace": true

Attachment of --inspect logs:

[vscode-node-debug2.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/871711/vscode-node-debug2.txt)

data.title: FR: Configurable wrapping column for git commit messages, default 72
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Linux Mint 18 (based on Ubuntu Xenial 16.04.2)

I'm asking for #2718 to be reopened, or for further discussion on the feature to be had in this issue. #2718 was closed because wrapping arbitrary-language text is really difficult (e.g., Thai has no spaces between words, and there is no algorithmic way to correctly break lines in between words; you have to have a Thai dictionary built into your program if you want correct linebreaks in Thai). However, there are two factors that make this an unimportant consideration for Git commit messages:

1. Any programming team that has more than one native language among the programmers in the team has probably already standardized on a single language, and that language is *almost* always English where spaces between words are normal.

2. There are very good reasons for NOT splitting lines in commit messages if those lines do not contain spaces, because those lines are probably URLs.

So the rule for Git commit message word wrapping should be very simple:

1. First line warns if it's more than 50 columns. (This is the current behavior).
2. Second line warns if it isn't blank.
3. Rest of the commit wraps on spaces (or on any whitespace, but I recommend sticking with plain `0x20` space characters only for simplicity) at a user-configurable column, defaulting to 72 since that's the current standard recommended by Git.
4. Any line in the commit that does NOT contain spaces does not wrap, but a warning pops up (similar to the warning if the first line is \> 50 columns) saying "Your commit message contains \# long line(s) which could not be wrapped because they do not contain spaces. If these lines are URLs, that's probably okay, but otherwise you should consider adding spaces so that the lines can be wrapped. Your settings are currently set to wrap any lines longer than 72 characters in your commit message." (With \#, of course, being substituted for the actual number of too-long lines in the message.)
5. That warning can be disabled in the user or workspace config settings, for the sake of any teams who have standardized on languages like Thai which do not use spaces in the language. The word-wrapping behavior can also be completely disabled if the user so desires, but it starts configured to be ON.
6. (Optional). If the long line starts with the regex `[a-zA-Z][-a-zA-Z+.]+:` (see [RFC 3986](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#section-3.1)), it is assumed to be a URL and no warning is issued for that line, since it's usually not desirable to split a URL across two or more lines.

This would go a long way towards making VS Code's Git message editor usable. As of right now, I avoid using VS Code's Git integration because it doesn't format Git messages correctly according to the coding standards of just about every project I've worked on. So despite the fact that VS Code has pretty good Git integration for most things, I still just Alt-Tab to a terminal and write my Git commits in Vim, where I *can* set it up to do the right thing for commit messages (wrap at 72 columns, or at 70 for one project I work on that has slightly stricter rules than most).

P.S. Also, as a side effect, I'd like to ask that the Git commit window NOT visually wrap lines that aren't truly wrapped (e.g., the only thing that causes text to go to the next line in the commit window is a real linefeed or CR/LF in the commit message). Instead, if the text goes past the end of the available window size, give us a horizontal scrollbar, which will serve as a cue to resize the Git sidebar to be large enough to fit 72 characters horizontally. And perhaps also there could a button that will automatically resize the Git sidebar to fit the text already in the commit message -- though that's a more "bells and whistles" feature, rather than core functionality.

data.title: vs code auto rearranging my code from hell
data.body:
I love spaces in code, but after the last update vs code auto rearranges all the code and removes the spaces... why 😓 how to stop this? - VSCode Version: Version 1.10.2 - OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Type some code with spaces ``` _.map( this.state.users, ( user, index ) { return

{ user.displayName }

} ``` 2. Hit enter 3. VS Code will rearrange the code like this: ``` _.map(this.state.users, (user,index) { return

{user.displayName}

} ``` How to stop this auto code formatting??? any settings i am missing? or a bug?

data.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T14:02:52.799Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601 - Extensions: |Extension|Author|Version| |---|---|---| |html-snippets|abusaidm|0.0.14| |jquerysnippets|donjayamanne|0.0.1| |vscode-html-css|ecmel|0.0.22| |beautify|HookyQR|0.1.8| |vscode-JS-CSS-HTML-formatter|lonefy|0.2.0| |cpptools|ms-vscode|0.8.1| |debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|0.5.2| |vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|1.6.6| |JavaScriptSnippets|xabikos|1.1.0| |html-css-class-completion|Zignd|0.0.2|; --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. 在标签里面添加style样式，之后选中从style开始，到style的最后一个引号"结束，删除该样式，此时剩余一个右"，这时会出现代码格式化问题，会自动在后面的代码中，在引号前面添加一个空格，导致某些带有ID的标签，出现问题，不能正常工作 2.我举例说明： 原始代码为：input type="checkbox" style="margin-left: 3px">XXS 后面带有其他的代码：div class="form-group"> 选中style="margin-left: 3px，并删除，此时变为XXS，这时，该段代码之后的所有代码在"前添加一个空格，变为div class="form-group ">select id="ClothType " style="outline-style:none "> 导致id比正常的多了一个空格

data.title: Move line autoindent#14390
data.body:
Main issue #14390
Another Issue in which it could be related #22093.

Questions, is there a way to test performances ?
The algorithm work like this:

- When moving lines, it will inherit the whitespaces of the next line.
- In some cases depending on the start or end of the line, if it's one of thoses chars []{}(): it will indent correctly the line

I created some tests, but I need to have some other feedbacks:

- Does the tests cover all the cases ?
- Could be possible performence issue ?
- Anything else that could be bad ?

For the issue #22093, they are talking aboit a different approache, after moving the lines, we use an auto indent functionality. Why not I would say but it seems for now the current autoindent feature isn't working well for selected code.

data.title: At EOL, two offsets map to same position in CRLF files
data.body:
In a CRLF document with the text:
```
asdf
asdf
```
the position (0, 4) would refer to the spot just after the first `f`. Calling `document.offsetAt(pos)` returns 4. Calling `document.positionAt(4)` returns (0, 4).

However, calling `document.positionAt(4+1)` also returns (0, 4).

In a LF document, calling `document.positionAt(4+1)` returns (1, 0).

My current use case is running through a document's text, moving right in the document by position:

```javascript
/**
 * The position one step right in the document
 * @param document the document to move in
 * @param pos the position to move from
 * @returns the position one step right, or null if last
 */
function posRight(document: vs.TextDocument, pos: vs.Position): vs.Position | null {
    let offset = document.offsetAt(pos)
    return offset < document.getText().length ? document.positionAt(offset + 1) : null
}
```

Moving up lines works, since in the double-mapping case `document.offsetAt(pos)` returns the lower of the two offsets.

My workaround currently is to compute the next position, compare it to the current position, and if they're the same to instead increment by two.

Any advice would be appreciated! This doesn't feel like intuitive behavior - my impression was that one offset mapped to one position, and vice versa.

Thanks!

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: OS X 10.11

data.title: Moveline autoindent#14390
data.body:
Main issue #14390 
Another Issue in which it could be related #22093.

Questions, is there a way to test performances ?
The algorithm work like this:

- When moving lines, it will inherit the whitespaces of the next line.
- In some cases depending on the start or end of the line, if it's one of thoses chars `[]{}():` it will indent correctly the line

I created some tests, but I need to have some other feedbacks:

- Does the tests cover all the cases ?
- Could be possible performence issue ? 
- Anything else that could be bad ?

For the issue #22093, they are talking aboit a different approache, after moving the lines, we use an auto indent functionality. Why not I would say but it seems for now the current autoindent feature isn't working well for selected code.

data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.10.2 - OS Version: w10 [Video](https://youtu.be/5GXhrCG5BOE) 1. Open file containing class with reference to other class B 2. Compilation error appears 3. Open file with class B 3. Error disappears Error from point 2 does no show up during console tsc cmpilation tsconfig.json ``` { "files":[ "app/**/*.ts", "app/**/*.js", "main.js", "renderer.js" ], "compilerOptions":{ "target":"es5", "module":"commonjs", "moduleResolution":"node", "sourceMap":false, "inlineSourceMap":true, "inlineSources":true, "allowJs":true, "rootDir":".", "outDir":"dist", "typeRoots":[ "./node_modules/@types" ] } ``` Listing each source file in files instead of "app/**/*.ts" resolves issue

data.title: Run command on session start of Integrated Terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.10.2
- OS Version:Windows 10 (1607)

Steps to Reproduce: N/A
Initialize a variable at start of bash when working using vscode. Since the path becomes too long, run command PS1='\u:\W\$ ' so that path string becomes short and max utilization of space.

data.title: Test: new commands to increase/decrease view size
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22645

- [x] anyOS - @weinand (macOS)
- [x] anyOS - @egamma 

New commands (`workbench.action.increaseViewSize` and `workbench.action.decreaseViewSize`) allow to increase or decrease a view (sidebar, editor or panel) size with keyboard only. 

Verify
* the commands work as advertised on the view that has current keyboard focus
* you cannot break the layout (e.g. minimal and maximal dimensions are respected)

data.title: Test: new setting to keep editor open when file deleted
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11642

- [x] Windows - @alexandrudima 
- [x] macOS - @chrisdias 
- [x] Linux - @aeschli 

A new setting `workbench.editor.closeOnFileDelete` allows to keep editors open even if the file on disk is deleted from outside VS Code (e.g. external terminal).

* verify this setting works and behaves as advertised
* verify the title updates back to normal when the file is restored
* test corner cases like deleting a dirty file, saving untitled file as file that was deleted, etc

data.title: editor.formatOnType Removes Spaces in JSDocs
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: all

Steps to Reproduce:

![issues vscode vscode-space](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1138623/24333560/6e739286-125a-11e7-809e-65e6ed1ecbbc.gif)

This behaviour bother me since a while, while writing code docs so I finally decided to create an issue for it.
It were nice if there were an option which aware of the initial space in the code doc blocks. How we see in the screencast is already an auto-creation functionality of the blocks, so this functionality would be definitely a part of the vscode core.

In almost every cases the space before any text there - so this extra key press can be avoided.

This appears:
- After initial code doc creation
- After line break
- Extra: If press delete on pos. 0 of a line and the before block line is an empty code block line (aware of space because it can be auto deleted if trailing spaces are removed automatically)

# EDIT

I found out this is an issue which only appear if ```editor.formatOnType``` option enabled! Any chance to fix this anyway if stick on this option?

data.title: Multiline parentheses break syntax theme
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2 (1.10.2)
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create new .js file
2. create arrow function which has multi line parameters, starting with parenthesis on 1.st line,
on 2nd line are the parameters, on 3rd line is the closing parenthesis
3. everything below 3rd line has broken syntax theme

Example code:

```
const mapPlayers = (
  players: Array<Player> = []
) => players.map(({ playerId, ...rest }) => ({ ...rest, player_id: playerId }))
```

Screenshot:
![image](http://i.imgur.com/EWMxu0T.gif)

Screenshot using default theme
![defaultTheme](http://i.imgur.com/ZPhDeSA.gif)

data.title: Feature request: Debug typescript with ts-node
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10
- OS Version: Arch linux x64
Is there any way to debug typescript file without compile it to js? I found ts-node package which can run typescript file directly in node environment, but I cannot config vscode to use it in debuging like this:
 "runtimeExecutable": "/path/to/ts-node",
            "outFiles": [
                "${workspaceRoot}/**/*"
            ]
